title: Remember that Ghostcrawler Video on RNG?
body:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5U1Gcf8l8yY

Here it is, for those who don't remember.

Now could someone explain to me how Kleptomancy's RNG does not fall under the ''Output RNG'' that Ghostcrawler said is not good for League?

I don't feel like I played better if I get 3 gold bags before first back. Nor do I feel like I got outplayed when all I get is mana pots and wards.

Considering this video shows that you guys over at Riot do understand what kind of RNG is good for a game like League, I really just don't get how on earth this thing hit live.

replies.body:
Hey you know I do remember that video

Meddler actually talked about this in one of his [Quick Gameplay Thoughts](https://boards.na.leagueoflegends.com/en/c/developer-corner/0RYiPNBI-quick-gameplay-thoughts-december-13) posts in December. I recommend taking a look at the whole post, since he covers a lot of different examples, but here's an excerpt about klepto.

> Kleptomancy - Somewhat randomized loot create a series of decisions to make around what to do with your new stuff and a bunch of exciting moments. Excessive impact of randomness is controlled by a large sample size (getting a lot of loot over the course of the game), controls on which items you can get at any point in time based off what you've recently got and how far into the game it is (no Elixir of Skill early on for example). Randomness on gold bags is also somewhat mitigated by players being able to choose to opt out of the randomized reward. Giving up another keystone also helps opponents respond to early spikes in power especially (lacking a combat keystone for direct trades).

IDK about others, but my issue with Klepto isn't over the course of the whole game; it's during the early phases, when a lucky potion drop suddenly gives him the advantage on trades. Or maybe I'm playing Teemo, hit 6, and start carefully setting up shrooms knowing that in order to counter them my opponent would have to do an early trinket swap (leaving them ward-less), only for him to suddenly pull an Oracles out of his rear and clear all my shrooms. Or any matchup where my opponent (playing a champion balanced around having no sustain) gets a lot of Health (and mana?) potions and can't be out-traded?

I can't plan around RNG. I can't counter-build it. All I can do is cross my fingers and HOPE that my enemy's early game drops are evenly distributed.

How is that any different to someone using three spells on you, and getting the damage of Electrocute? Or hitting you with Grasp of the Ancients? They get momentary points of power, but other keystones give that power 24/7, and more reliably. You talk about these best case scenarios, but what if the person with Klepto gets an Oracles versus a Darius. 

You're substituting 24/7 available keystones, for possibly more diverse answers.

But that's the thing. Klepto has extreme highs and lows that can't be played around. If the opponent happens to draw the perfect item from the random pool, you just got dicked on without any skill or counterplay. Other keystones are consistent in what they do, so you know what to expect at any given time.

I'm sorry I still don't get it. Yeah, you can get some highs with Klepto, but why can't you use your more consistent keystone to beat that? You don't need to rely on getting something to do your job, you can do your job whenever you want. And, I'm sorry again, but how are things like Electrocute any different?? 

You can't play around the damage from Electrocute already more than you would normally play. "Dodge things" as counterplay to electrocute, is the same as fighting someone with Kleptomancy. Phase Rush doesn't give you any room to deny their speed buff, as much as you would while fighting someone with Kleptomancy. Keystones naturally have a form of power that can't be played against.

 Kleptomancy just gives that power in different ways, in exchange for not being 24/7 and consistent

Would it help to mention that what they're talking about has a lot to do with perception and real-time analysis, and that the unpredictability of klepto ruins a lot of that for players to some degree?

Let's take your example of Klepto vs Electrocute, or even someone having summoner spells/abilities up. Everything in that sentence you can actively plan around and account for in your decision making within reason *except*for Klepto. 

I can look up the early damage values of electrocute and plan around that. "I'm at 30% and my opponent has electrocute up. I probably shouldn't try to fight right now because that will give them enough damage to all in me unless they waste X ability because that's what gives them enough to proc it." 

I can look up the cooldown for Lulu polymorph, and decide not to dive Lulu while she has it up. I can decide not to try and all in bot lane when they have summoners up and we don't because I know just how big of an advantage it gives them or decide to all in them because we have summs and they dont and the 90hp base on heal will be enough to come out of top.

With Klepto, the level of RNG is so high that it becomes really hard to plan and make decisions around it. Do I just never decide to trade pre-3 because klepto might give them an additional skill point mid fight and suddenly they have access to another skill? "Nah, the chances of that are really low", but if it happens I get screwed. You can clear their vision and abuse the fact that they've used all their trinket wards until klepto suddenly gives them another and your sweeper is now on cd. But how you can account for that? How can you account for every single situation where klepto might have an unexpected "high" that will turn the tide of the fight and do that constantly in real time scenarios on top of all the other things you have to think about during the game? You can't in a meaningful way which is the problem people have with it. You can't just never try to trade with someone because they *might* get a pot mid fight. At least with crit, you have a percentage that can be used to estimate how often a *single* thing (bonus damage) may happen.
Thank you, you covered exactly what I would have when I was going to reply.

> You can clear their vision and abuse the fact that they've used all their trinket wards until klepto suddenly gives them another and your sweeper is now on cd.

And that's a choice they can choose, just like how I can choose to add another 100 or so damage to an early game combo. Inspiration is about handling situations outside of outright power, being able to have more vision in exchange for damage is the trade off. Getting gold for item powerspikes, instead of combo damage is the trade off.

 Why should you be able meaningfully respond to something that isn't damage? Sure ya can get a few temporary points of AP and AD from Klepto, but those don't account at all for the difference between an actual damage keystone.

The problem is that they didn't *choose* "ward". They *chose* "Let's play wheel of fortune on every proc". This isn't about direct power vs indirect power. I only mentioned direct power when talking about crit in that it is a singular function. Even the things in Inspiration you mention can be accounted for to a meaningful degree. 

If my opponent has future market, I can expect them to have a gold advantage on recall even if we have the exact same farm and no kill participation. 

If there's a keystone that says "Hey, you get to have an extra ward out on the field" I can account for that. 

The problem with Klepto isn't that it's "invisible power" or indirect power. The problem is that it's spontaneous power, with no predictable pattern and that can be *very* polarizing early game. Maybe they'll get actual damage boost, maybe a free skill point, maybe a ward when they really need it, maybe it'll be useless all lane. I can never know what to expect from it in a game that already demands a lot of learned knowledge and information juggling/tracking. At no point am I arguing that every tree should have direct damage as the value. That would be terrible and defeat the point of separate trees to begin with.

If they plan to keep klepto as the concept it currently is, they need to retune it's early game impact and/or functionality in the same way that they need to retune "I'm suddenly winning lane super hard because of a crit" Tryndamere. I personally don't even have a problem with its state mid/late game.

>Klepto has extreme highs and lows that can't be played around.

It's been specifically nerfed to make the drops more regular and consistent.

Here's what I don't get: if the argument to stuff like Klepto or crit is that it generates no meaningful variance when averaged out over a long enough period of time, then the RNG powering it is pointless, because you could very well achieve the same results with some non-random system. If the counter-argument to that is that the randomness does, in fact, generate meaningful moment-to-moment variance, then that in itself disproves the initial argument that those RNG mechanics don't disrupt the game. You cannot have both. 

What has also bothered me significantly about Riot's recent stance on RNG is that it feels like it tunnel-visions on the pure statistical aspects of the mechanic, without taking into account player perception, which is the real issue. For sure, any RNG system can be made to average out over a long enough period of time, but raw power isn't the main reason why people dislike stuff like Kleptomancy or Spell Thief. Even if both were horribly underpowered, I could guarantee you that those systems would still be unpopular, because having a champion-to-champion interaction be colored by any kind of innate RNG _feels inherently unfair_. Players do not reason in terms of statistics over time, they perceive gameplay from moment to moment. Therefore, whenever there is a high moment generated by randomness (which is a low moment for the opponent), that _specific_ moment will always feel unfair. This is an instance where subjective player perception is more meaningful than pure statistics, and so I urge you to reconsider RNG mechanics with a focus on the former, rather than the latter.
Underrated comment.

As always, well said man.

Your insight on a discussion is always a welcome one as far as I'm concerned.

Thank you, and likewise! I very much appreciate that you made this thread, because I also think that there's been a clear disconnect between Riot's stance on RNG and the way they've been implementing it, just as has happened before with other parts of their design philosophy. Because there's been this running issue of the devs saying one thing and then doing another, it worries me as a player, not just because it makes me unsure of what will happen with League next, but also because it makes me question whether there really is a solid design philosophy driving these decisions, or whether those decisions are made first, and only afterwards does some public statement get written to justify them. Threads like this one promote accountability and consistency, both of which I think are features Riot has room to improve upon when it comes to communicating with the playerbase.

Every rng has no place in league not just the output rng
I am more of refering to crit

Elemental dragons are almost ok
Crit is still output rng; that's why it's bad. I'm very confident that if Riot were designing League from the ground up today, crit would not exist in its current form.

> [{quoted}](name=KempyreanPirate,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=iYfKE9Hl,comment-id=00030001,timestamp=2018-02-14T19:47:42.732+0000)
>
> Crit is still output rng; that's why it's bad. I'm very confident that if Riot were designing League from the ground up today, crit would not exist in its current form.

Most of us that hat crit have given ample solutions on how to change it, but riot still does nothing about it and doesn't even comment on it. Its frustrating and makes it feel like your beating your head on a break wall.
{{sticker:sg-janna}}

I think that's really unfair.

Riot has said that they don't love the current crit mechanics; last I heard them comment on it, they said that they wouldn't touch something that big until they finished runes reforged, which we *also* clamored for, as a community.

Guess what they just finished working on? (hint: Runes Reforged)

And guess what Meddler is gearing up to post about in the next couple weeks? (hint: it's marksmen and crit)

I don't think we clamored for this runes. I don't think there's a single person that likes this season.

I will say they have said things, but have they said and actually done anything? Talk is all fine and good but its just that. Talk. Talk is cheap, i want to see action.

I am just an old fart like that, I expect action before giving credit for any work. Just how i was raised. Guess you could call me an old fossil. I am harsh and criticize hard, but give credit and praise when work is done and complete and shown.
{{sticker:sg-ahri-2}}

It's not cool to dismiss hyper-critical comments as "old fart" behavior, imo.

I'm an old fart, too, but I understand that things take time. You can't expect someone to earn a Bachelor's degree in one year, for instance. It just takes longer than that. 

It's fine to say that they don't get cred until they deliver, and I agree. But they deserve the space to deliver that before acting like you're "beating your head against a brick wall." As I said above, that isn't fair. It isn't helpful feedback, and it doesn't help anything go faster.

> [{quoted}](name=KempyreanPirate,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=iYfKE9Hl,comment-id=000300010000000000000000,timestamp=2018-02-14T20:41:48.930+0000)
>

> I'm an old fart, too, but I understand that things take time. You can't expect someone to earn a Bachelor's degree in one year, for instance. It just takes longer than that. 
> 
> It's fine to say that they don't get cred until they deliver, and I agree. But they deserve the space to deliver that before acting like you're "beating your head against a brick wall." As I said above, that isn't fair. It isn't helpful feedback, and it doesn't help anything go faster.

Sorry but I gotta side with jinx on this one. With them adding more RNG to the game and having left crit be in its current state for so long I agree it sounds much more like them talking saying "we're working on it" but doing nothing.

not so sure, they said RNG is bad pretty early in the day(remember dodge?), yet they haven't used any opportunity to work on crit.
Especially the adc update in S6 would have been THE opportunity to rework Crit into a no-rng mechanic, but all they did was throwing more crit into the game, and crit RNG with many possible solutions has been discussed since i first went active on the boards in S2, and probably long befor that aswell...
If you read some of their design statments/philosophies, you'd think they really know their shit, but for some reason they just don't translate that into the actuall game but rather go into the opposite direction with their actuall gamepla changes.
It buffels me again and again how they can actually say smart things like GC on randomness and yet act totally against that soon after like with klepto and Zoe's W...there just seems to be a MASSIVE discrapency between their theoretical background and the actuall execution in the game...

Crit RNG may be that necessary evil. If crit did not exist then there would be 4-5 ADCs only (those who can use lethality to the best effect, Vayne and Ezreal) and every one of them (save Ezreal) would just build lifesteal items because just having attack speed but no damage is useless in short fights unless you can sustain.

that's some small box thinking right here.
Reworking crit doesn't have to mean you just remove it out right which for me is what you imply.
The easiest way would be to chance it in a simple % damage increase on AAs, it would keep all the funktionallity from crit but instead of coming in RNG based spikes, it's simply the streamlined average.
Riot even succesfully went that path with the ashe rework in S5...

However, i would prefer more drastic changes, as for me crit comes with more issues than just the RNG. It's multiplicative nature causes all AA based champs to naturally hyperscale, and since it only affects AAs it moves focus away froma  champions kit onto that very casic move while concentrateing the highest damage of the game on ranged point n click that offers no counterplay other than 'stay away'.
**Obviously** itmeisation and current cirt users would need some major work if crit was not only changed in it's rng but also it's fuktion or simply got removed, hence why the marksmen update would have been perfect for adressing it since they worked on nearly all crit users anyway with that update.

Excellent critique. When they do get around to working on crit (or before that, I'm not picky), it would be great to hear some explanation about what was holding them up. I imagine they have an answer, but I think it would be really nice for the player base to see it. Just one man's opinion.

Crit RNG exists because auto-attacks as a mechanic are very unexciting because the result is so predictable and monotonous. There isn't really any variation in gameplay between attacks. Crit chance makes auto-attack play-patterns more exciting by having something with actual variance which can affect the outcome. Note that this isn't something that I exactly agree with, and I feel low crit chance especially (when you have 1 or 2 crit items or when your {{champion:23}}) can have a toxic effect on the game.

> [{quoted}](name=KempyreanPirate,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=iYfKE9Hl,comment-id=00030001,timestamp=2018-02-14T19:47:42.732+0000)
>
> Crit is still output rng; that's why it's bad. I'm very confident that if Riot were designing League from the ground up today, crit would not exist in its current form.

They need to do something about Crit. Being clicked for 1k damage with a Statikk boosted crit is rage inducing.

> [{quoted}](name=Done25,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=iYfKE9Hl,comment-id=000300010003,timestamp=2018-02-15T00:03:21.679+0000)
>
> They need to do something about Crit. Being clicked for 1k damage with a Statikk boosted crit is rage inducing.

Make crit work like it does on Ashe: Just another multiplier instead of sometimes a big multiplier and sometimes no multiplier at all.
Yep, the problem is that crit is so tied to the game's roots, is almost impossible to rework/remove it. I hope they try someday though.

I've got my fingers crossed. I *do* think it will be hard, but I don't think it's anywhere close to impossible. They're just gonna have to move slow and do serious vetting on it internally before even *thinking* about bringing it to PBE. 

And then it should be there awhile during changes. I think the way they approached runes is the right way to approach crit. It can't just be 1-2 guys working on it and hoping for the best. Gotta be slow, gotta be calculated.

Wht if they made crit work like energizer item . More you build up the damage the next auto you do is assured to be a extra damage hit . It would be similar to a certain duskblade but damage can be tone down .

That's up to debate.
But Kleptomancy is the exact type of RNG that Riot stated doesn't have a place in the game.

If Klepto wants to be "Ghostcrawle-approved" then it should have a cooldown, and when conditionally triggered when off-CD it will present the player running the rune with a choice between various things that they could get, and the player has to make choices between for instance, getting either gold or potion or ward.

Though tbh, I also kinda feel if implemented like this it might be a bit too OP and versatile in some sense, given Klepto is already quite busted even without player agency.
That's not "Ghostcrawler-approved randomness", that's just not random at all.

very good suggestion

but limit the choices, remove elexir of skill for instance

Klepto feels god awful right now. I play Ezreal, and a lot of games I'll have to play safe and just Q poke, and I'll have a 400 gold lead before level 5 because I got good RNG. I don't feel like I really earned it, and I feel like I'd literally be trolling if I take any other keystone. Then the next game, I'm winning lane, and Q'ing people on cooldown non-stop for 10 minutes and I've got next to no gold, some potions, and some wards I can't use without going to top side midlane because there's so much coverage between my trinket, my jg, and my support already. In those games, I feel like I'm trolling for taking Klepto instead of the other way around. It's so inconsistent that I honestly don't know if it's going to be worth it over another keystone in a given game. Some games I'll say "Yeah, this is definitely going better than if I took Press the Attack, Aery, Comet, Electrocute or even a fully stacked Dark Harvest right now.", but the very next I could be thinking "Jesus, I might as well have Predator if I want a gold income rune so I can use it to escape when I greed for this extra wave"

I still don't like plants...

I mean, they're a very **VERY** minor nuisance, but just dislike them a lot compared to the Jungle Buffs we had in 2016. Those were so much fun to play around :(

> [{quoted}](name=Triistana,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=iYfKE9Hl,comment-id=0008,timestamp=2018-02-14T22:27:15.945+0000)
>
> I still don't like plants...
> 
> I mean, they're a very **VERY** minor nuisance, but just dislike them a lot compared to the Jungle Buffs we had in 2016. Those were so much fun to play around :(

you didn't play around those at all tho.
Yeah I did... What's this comment even??

You only played around it if, by playing around it, you mean you ignored it 99% of the time, and the only thing you did against it was drop a ward on their raptors.

There was no playing around Krug smite Buff - it was just there. It only did a tiny bit of bonus damage to a turret once, or stunned monsters.
There was no playing around Red or Blue smite buff - it just gave a burst of health and mana. (The former has been added to all large monster smites)
There was no playing around Wolf smite buff - It was done and then basically ignored. Plus it was the most useless buff ever, because you'd have already cleared your entire blue side when you smited it.
There was no playing around Gromp smite buff - it was a fucking joke for damage, and there was no way to avoid it in the slightest.
The only interaction you ever had with Raptor smite buff was putting a ward on it to waste their buff.

I **DID** use them but whatever dude... if this is that important to you
http://i0.kym-cdn.com/entries/icons/original/000/007/508/neildegrasse.jpg

> [{quoted}](name=Triistana,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=iYfKE9Hl,comment-id=000800000000,timestamp=2018-02-15T01:19:59.384+0000)

No you didnt. You "figured out the rubxi cube" and just repeated the clear path every game.

Outaide of raptor buff, non of them actually contributed to the gameplay in  any significant way beyond " which buff will let my chosen champ clear" which is over and done with as soon as you figure it out in your first game.

So what you're telling is one of two...

a) You think you know how every single League player used camps, and given how many millions play, I'd say you have a problem
b) You somehow were stalking someone who you thought it was me and think I never used the buffs

Not sure which one is worse.
I think that Ghostcrawler left?  Maybe he was the only one making sure that RNG fo this sort staye out of lol

Pretty sure he's still around.
And I have no idea how involved he was in the rune update, wether or not he actually had to give the individual runes a green light or something.

But I didn't make this thread to start pointing fingers at individual Rioters. I made this thread because I genuinly believe this rune has no place in this game, and I don't understand how it made it to live in the first place.

Did he?

Cause i've never heard or seen of her and right now im wondering if she replaced baldcrawler?

I am quite sure I shouldnt be enthusiastic about a girl being in charge in a workplace primarly dominated by man. Atleast I assume 89% rioters are male or so. Whats the chance of her being the most quallified person there 

The whole goal of opening up botlane is also extremly concerning
